awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is the microscopic theory of the strong interactions that allows us to understand how hadrons, such as the proton, neutron and pion, are formed. In turn, nucleons (protons and neutrons) make up more than 99% of the mass of the visible matter of the universe. Nucleons are composed of quarks and gluons (partons), the fundamental particles of QCD. The structure of the nucleon is studied using high-energy scattering processes at state-of-the-art experimental facilities in the USA and abroad. This project will provide theoretical guidance and help analyze experimental data generated at those experimental facilities.  Furthermore, the PI will mentor graduate students and engage in outreach activities addressing high school students, teachers, and undergraduate students.

The project will primarily concentrate on two topics in hadronic physics.  First, a new fit of the transversity distribution will be performed for di-hadron production, which is generally considered a very clean channel.  After a careful leading-order analysis, the transversity will be extracted in a collinear next-to-leading (NLO) order framework.  This requires, in particular, the first-ever challenging NLO calculation of the relevant di-hadron observables in electron-positron annihilation, lepton-nucleon scattering and proton-proton collision.  This study is expected to shed new light on the longstanding tension between information on the nucleon's transversity from experimental data on the one hand and from lattice QCD on the other.  The second part of the project deals with partonic Wigner functions.  For a number of reasons, partonic Wigner functions have attracted enormous interest over the last years.  Despite their importance, presently no experimental information is available on these objects.  The main focus will therefore be on observables for Wigner functions.  This includes numerical estimates of observables, the calculation of higher-order corrections, and the search for new processes in which Wigner functions show up.  Special attention will be paid to the question about how a future electron-ion collider (EIC) can further this research area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
High-energy scattering processes can be used to explore in detail quantum chromodynamics (QCD), the generally accepted microscopic theory of the strong interaction.  They allow us to understand how hadrons are formed through partons, that is, quarks and gluons which are the "building blocks" of QCD.  The project has been dealing with several topics in this field, leading to 12 regular publications.  The results were presented at a number of international meetings and in seminars, by the PI, his graduate students, and other collaborators. 

We regard the following points as the most important intellectual outcomes of the project:

(1) Partonic quasi-distributions: Recent developments allow one to compute parton distribution functions (PDFs) in lattice QCD by using so-called quasi-PDFs.  The quasi-PDFs are related to the light-cone PDFs, which are accessible in experiment, through a matching procedure in perturbative QCD.  At present, this approach can have (significant) impact in areas where experimental data are sparse.  This applies to so-called generalized parton distributions (GPDs) and higher-twist PDFs.  We investigated, for the first time, the usefulness of this approach for GPDs, which play a key role for 3D-imaging of hadrons.  We found that the quasi-GPDs must satisfy certain model-independent constraints that can be exploited to study systematic uncertainties of lattice calculations.  Furthermore, we obtained pioneering matching results for higher-twist PDFs, which also allowed us to obtain the very first results for those quantities in lattice QCD.

(2) Mass sum rules in QCD: Understanding in QCD the mass of strongly interacting systems, such as the nucleon, is of utmost importance.  This topic was studied in the past, leading to different decompositions (sum rules) for the proton mass in the literature.  All of them are related to matrix elements of the QCD energy-momentum tensor (EMT).  We revisited this topic and came up with a new mass sum rule.  The main difference to the most frequently used sum rule is the absence of a contribution from the well-known trace anomaly of the EMT, which a priori does not enter the QCD Hamiltonian (and as such the hadron mass) according to our finding.  This result is also critical for the science of the future electron-ion collider (EIC).

(3) Monte Carlo analysis of PDFs: Measurements of deep-inelastic lepton nucleon scattering (DIS) have played and keep playing an important role in providing information about quark and gluon PDFs in the nucleon.  We used modern Monte Carlo techniques to extract (unpolarized) quark PDFs of the nucleon from DIS data for proton, deuteron, helium-3 and triton targets, where the most important finding of our work is related to the light nuclear targets.  For a free nucleon, the isospin symmetry of QCD implies, for instance, that the up-quark PDF for a proton and the down-quark PDF for a neutron are identical.  Our analysis which, in particular, made use of recent data from the
MARATHON Collaboration at Jefferson Lab, indicates that such symmetry relations can be broken for (bound) nucleons inside a nucleus.  This is an important finding which may significantly impact the field of nuclear PDFs, where isospin symmetry for bound nucleons is routinely used.

(4) Yellow Report of the EIC Users Group: The EIC, to be built over the next decade at Brookhaven National Lab, will allow one to study the structure of strongly interacting systems at a new level.  The Yellow Report of the EIC Users Group, completed in March 2021 (after about 1.5 years) and signed by more than 300 authors, discussed in detail the detector requirements for the EIC and also provided an up-to-date presentation of the EIC science.  The PI served as one of the four main conveners of the Physics Working Group for the report.  Both PhD students of the PI also contributed to and became co-authors of the Yellow Report.

 

The broader impact of the project has been primarily in the training of graduate students and in outreach events.  Two students were involved in the activities.  The main goal of their training was to prepare them for careers in areas such as continued work in fundamental physics research, work in industry, or administrative positions at the borderline of research and industry.  Both students were instrumental in moving forward several of the projects.  They gave presentations at national and international conferences, as well as invited seminars.  Both secured an award from Temple University for excellent research.  One of them recently got a postdoc position in the Theory Group of Brookhaven National Lab.  The other student, who just completed four years in the graduate program, got a prestigious SCGSR Award from the DOE.

The PI gave several outreach-type presentations, focusing on how we can understand the mass of everyday objects at the subatomic level in QCD. Those presentations, for undergraduate and high school students, were well received.
